article: National Conference today said the Centre’s recognition to the Jammu and Kashmir government’s effort of conducting successful panchayat polls is a major jolt for those who had tried to misguide masses over the issue.“The conduct of panchayat elections was not only a sincere effort of the coalition government headed by Chief Minister Omar Abdullah for the empowerment of people at the grassroot level but also historic as NC ensured establishment of Panchayat Raj after a gap of more than 30 years,” NC provincial spokesman Sajad Ahmed Kichloo said.Kichloo congratulated State Chief Secretary Madhav Lal and DGP Kuldeep Khuda for being conferred with prestigious Prime Minister’s Award for Excellence in Public Administration.The NC spokesman slammed the PDP for failing to set up Panchayat Raj institution during its regime.“Instead of appreciating the efforts of the government,the opposition leaders are out with their propaganda machinery against the government…,” he said.You May LikeGopal Khemka, a prominent businessman and owner of Magadh Hospital, was fatally shot near his residence in Patna. This comes six years after his son's murder in a similar manner. Khemka is reportedly associated with the BJP and was shot at close range by unidentified assailants. Police are investigating the incident and examining CCTV footage to determine the motive.
summary: The National Conference (NC) praised the Indian government's recognition of the Jammu and Kashmir administration's successful conduct of panchayat elections, describing it as a significant setback for those misleading the public on the issue. NC provincial spokesman Sajad Ahmed Kichloo emphasized that the elections marked a historic effort by the coalition government led by Chief Minister Omar Abdullah to empower citizens at the grassroots level, re-establishing Panchayat Raj after over 30 years. He congratulated State Chief Secretary Madhav Lal and DGP Kuldeep Khuda for receiving the Prime Minister’s Award for Excellence in Public Administration. Kichloo criticized the People's Democratic Party (PDP) for not implementing Panchayat Raj during its tenure, accusing opposition leaders of spreading propaganda against the current government instead of acknowledging its achievements.

headline: Temple ordinance should include all shrines of Valley: APMCC
article: Seeking inclusion of all Hindu shrines in the Kashmir Valley under the purview of a proposed ordinance on protection of temples,a Kashmiri Pandits’ body today asked the Jammu and Kashmir government to make public the contents of the order before its enforcement.“The state government should declare the contents of the ordinance regarding protection of temples in Kashmir before promulgating it. It should not end up being an eye-wash,” Vinood Pandita,Chairman of All Parties Migrants Coordination Committee,told reporters here.Terming the assurance of Chief Minister Omar Abdullah regarding protection of temples as a good step,Pandita,however,pointed that even though the government could have passed the pending Bill in this regard in the recent Assembly session,it chose to “hoodwink” the Kashmiri Pandits.He warned the government against any move to exclude temples managed by specific individuals or trusts from the ordinance.Pandita also said the temples in the Valley should be fully controlled by Kashmiri Pandits as it will serve as a big confidence building measure for the community.You May LikeGopal Khemka, a prominent businessman and owner of Magadh Hospital, was fatally shot near his residence in Patna. This comes six years after his son's murder in a similar manner. Khemka is reportedly associated with the BJP and was shot at close range by unidentified assailants. Police are investigating the incident and examining CCTV footage to determine the motive.
summary: A Kashmiri Pandits' organization has urged the Jammu and Kashmir government to publicly disclose the contents of a proposed ordinance aimed at protecting Hindu temples in the Kashmir Valley before its implementation. Vinood Pandita, Chairman of the All Parties Migrants Coordination Committee, emphasized the need for transparency to ensure the ordinance is not merely a façade. While he acknowledged Chief Minister Omar Abdullah's assurances regarding temple protection as a positive step, he criticized the government's decision not to pass a related Bill in the recent Assembly session, suggesting it misled the Kashmiri Pandit community. Pandita also insisted that all temples in the Valley should be managed by Kashmiri Pandits to foster trust and confidence within the community.

headline: Jharkhand: 1 dead, more feared trapped after portion of coal mine collapses in Ramgarh district
article: One person was killed and some others were feared trapped after a portion of a coal mine collapsed during “illegal” mining inJharkhand‘s Ramgarh district, police said on Saturday. The incident occurred in the early hours at Karma area in the district. An administrative team has been dispatched for relief and rescue operation, they said. “One body has been recovered so far and rescue operation is underway, as more people are suspected to be trapped,” Kuju Police Outpost in-charge Ashutosh Kumar Singh told PTI. He said that some villagers were involved in “illegal” mining of coal at the site. Ramgarh Deputy Commissioner (DC) Faiz Aq Ahmed Mumtaz told PTI: “We received information about the incident in the morning. An administrative team has been sent to the spot to investigate the matter.”
summary: A portion of a coal mine collapsed during illegal mining in the Karma area of Jharkhand's Ramgarh district, resulting in one confirmed death and fears that others may be trapped. The incident occurred early Saturday morning. Authorities, including the police and district administration, have launched a rescue and relief operation. Kuju Police Outpost in-charge Ashutosh Kumar Singh confirmed the recovery of one body and stated that villagers were engaged in illegal coal mining at the site. Ramgarh Deputy Commissioner Faiz Aq Ahmed Mumtaz said an administrative team has been dispatched to investigate the incident.

headline: Agriculture technocrats call off hunger strike
article: Agriculture technocrats in Jammu and Kashmir today called off their month-long hunger strike following an assurance by the government that their demands,including regularisation of services,would be considered.The technocrats called off their stir after the advisor to Chief Minister,Mubarak Gul,assured the Jammu and Kashmir Agricultural Technocrats Association that all their genuine demands would be redressed.Gul,who met protesting agriculturist today,said Chief Minister Omar Abdullah is committed to resolving their demands regarding absorption in government jobs on seniority basis,enhancement in stipend and various other issues.Following an assurance by him,the protesters called off their strike.You May LikeGopal Khemka, a prominent businessman and owner of Magadh Hospital, was fatally shot near his residence in Patna. This comes six years after his son's murder in a similar manner. Khemka is reportedly associated with the BJP and was shot at close range by unidentified assailants. Police are investigating the incident and examining CCTV footage to determine the motive.
summary: Agriculture technocrats in Jammu and Kashmir ended their month-long hunger strike after receiving assurances from the government regarding their demands. The protest concluded following a meeting with Mubarak Gul, advisor to the Chief Minister, who pledged that the government would address the technocrats' requests, including regularization of services and absorption into government jobs based on seniority. Chief Minister Omar Abdullah has expressed his commitment to resolving these issues. In a separate incident, businessman Gopal Khemka was fatally shot near his home in Patna, marking a tragic event six years after his son's murder under similar circumstances. Khemka, reportedly linked to the BJP, was attacked by unidentified assailants, and police are currently investigating the case and reviewing CCTV footage to uncover the motive.

headline: Jammu and Kashmir: 36 Amarnath pilgrims suffer minor injuries after 5 buses collide in Ramban
article: At least 36Amarnathpilgrims suffered minor injuries when five buses slammed into each other in Ramban district on Saturday, officials said. The buses were part of a convoy headed for Pahalgam base camp in south Kashmir from Jammu’s Bhagwati Nagar. The accident took place near Chanderkoot, along the Jammu-Srinagar National Highway, at around 8 am, officials said. They said the collision occurred due to the failure of the brakes of one of the buses in the convoy. “The last vehicle of the Pahalgam convoy lost control and hit stranded vehicles at the Chanderkot Langer site, damaging four vehicles and causing minor injuries to 36 Yatris,” Ramban Deputy Commissioner Mohammad Alyas Khan said. He said the government officials already present at the site rushed the injured to the Ramban district hospital. Several senior police officers visited the hospital to monitor the treatment of the injured and directed the chief medical officer to ensure the best care. “The Yatris were later shifted to other vehicles for their onward journey,” the deputy commissioner said. Ramban Medical Superintendent Sudarshan Singh Katoch said the pilgrims were discharged immediately after first aid. The convoy left for its destination after the damaged buses were replaced, officials said. The fourth batch of 6,979 pilgrims — 5,196 men, 1,427 women, 24 children, 331 sadhus and sadhvis, and one transgender — left the Bhagwati Nagar base camp in two separate convoys between 3.30 am and 4.05 am. While 4,226 pilgrims left in 161 vehicles for Nunwan base camp for the 48-kilometre traditional Pahalgam route, 2,753 pilgrims were headed for the shorter but steeper 14-kilometre Baltal route in 151 vehicles.
summary: At least 36 Amarnath pilgrims sustained minor injuries when five buses collided in a convoy near Chanderkoot in Jammu and Kashmir’s Ramban district on Saturday morning. The convoy was en route from Jammu’s Bhagwati Nagar to the Pahalgam base camp. Officials reported that the accident occurred due to brake failure in one of the buses, which then hit stranded vehicles, damaging four buses. The injured pilgrims were quickly taken to the Ramban district hospital and later discharged after receiving first aid. Authorities ensured proper care and arranged alternate vehicles for the pilgrims to continue their journey. The incident involved members of the fourth batch of 6,979 pilgrims, who had departed early morning for both the Pahalgam and Baltal routes of the Amarnath Yatra.

headline: ‘India 2nd most confident country’
article: Indians continue to be among the world’s most confident people about their economy on account of moderating inflationary pressure and the easing of tight money policy stance of the Reserve Bank,says a report.According to global research firm Ipsos,India has emerged as the second most economically confident nation for the second consecutive time.India’s economic confidence jumped by five points to 75 per cent in March compared to the previous month,to retain the second most economically confident nation title after Saudi Arabia which tops the table with 89 per cent.China is the third most economically confident country,where 71 per cent are optimistic about their economy,followed by Sweden (70 per cent),Germany (68 per cent),Canada (64 per cent) and Australia (62 per cent).“India has overtaken Japan to become the third-largest economy in terms of purchasing power parity (as per IMF report) and is heading for accelerated growth,following RBI cutting repo rate by 50 bps and inflation moderating to acceptable level,” Ipsos India CEO Mick Gordon said.“This should provide some confidence to the overall sentiments and help in stimulating investment. If the inflation momentum eases in near future,it will give RBI more room to cut rates further to boost investments and growth,” he added.More than half of Indian citizens (56 per cent) believe their economy,which impacts their personal finances,is good and 57 per cent people expect that the economy in their local area will be stronger in the next six months,the report said.Gordon said global economic indicators are disturbing,as it is evident that the sources of external growth that the Indian economy has been relying upon in the last few years will be week.“In order to further strengthen domestic demand and improve investor confidence,government has to improve the conditions for private investment,address infrastructure bottlenecks,enhance governance and public service delivery,” he added.The report,which examined citizens’ assessment of the current state of their country’s economy said the overall global average economic confidence remained swung up one point at 39 percent last month.Looking ahead,34 per cent global citizens surveyed said their local economy would be stronger six months from now. The natives of Brazil are the quite optimistic about about the state of their economy in the next six months,followed by Saudi Arabia and India.The survey was conducted in March this year among nearly 19,000 people in 24 countries.Gopal Khemka, a prominent businessman and owner of Magadh Hospital, was fatally shot near his residence in Patna. This comes six years after his son's murder in a similar manner. Khemka is reportedly associated with the BJP and was shot at close range by unidentified assailants. Police are investigating the incident and examining CCTV footage to determine the motive.
summary: A report by global research firm Ipsos reveals that India ranks as the second most economically confident country, with 75% of its citizens optimistic about the economy, a five-point increase from the previous month. This marks India's sustained position behind Saudi Arabia, which leads at 89%. The report attributes this confidence to moderating inflation and the Reserve Bank of India's recent interest rate cuts. Over half of Indians (56%) view the economy positively, with 57% expecting local economic improvement in the next six months. However, Ipsos India CEO Mick Gordon cautions that external economic conditions remain troubling, urging the government to enhance private investment and address infrastructure issues. The survey, conducted in March among nearly 19,000 people across 24 countries, reflects a slight global economic confidence increase to 39%.
